Description: One of the world's most spectacular flowering trees. It is a robust tree, grows between 7 to 25 m (23 to 82 ft) tall and is native to tropical dry forests of Africa. It has a dense, dark, shining, green crown.The tree has a stout, tapering, somewhat buttressed trunk covered in warty light gray bark. The lateral branches are short and thick. This tree is planted extensively as an ornamental tree throughout the tropics.
Leaves2: Bronze when young and Glossy, deep green when mature
Leaves4: Leaflets(Upto 15cm long) are deeply veined
Flowers3: Flower bud contains water and it is ampule shaped
Fruits3: Turn from green to brown as they mature
Fruits4: Each pod contains about 500 tissue papery seeds
Location: Beside Convo hall, Inside H4, Near CSRE bulding, Near Campus hub

Description: Cassia fistula, known as the golden rain tree or golden shower tree, is a flowering plant in the family Fabaceae. It is widely grown as an ornamental plant in tropical and subtropical area, blooms in late spring and flowering is extravagant, with trees being covered with yellow flowers, many times with almost no leaf is visible. It's flower is the state flower of Kerala and it is national tree of Thailand.
Leaves3: Three to eight pairs of leaflets
Leaves4: Each leaflet 7 to 21cm long and 4 to 9cm broad
Bark1: Grey, smooth to slightly ridged and slender,
Bark2: Young twigs sparsely to densely hairy.
Flowers2: Five yellow petals of equal size and shape
Flowers4: They are produced in pendulous racemes which are 20 to 40 cm long
Fruits3: 30 to 60 cm long and 1.5 to 2.5cm broad
Fruits4: Contain dark brown flattish seeds (Around 100 in one pod)
Location: Entrance of H15, Inside H12, Beside Jalvihar building(Eastside)

Description: Amla is small to medium size plant. It grows to the height of 8 to18 meter. It has a crooked trunk and spreading branches, and they are shown to possess properties that can combat age related diseases such as cancer, diabetis, cardiac ailments etc.The plant is commonly cultivated in the home garden, especially in India, for its edible fruit and as a medicinal plant.
Leaves4: Resemble like pinnate leaves
Bark3: Its wood is hard in texture
Flowers2: Have six segments with no real petals
Flowers3: Male and female flowers are carried seperately
Flowers4: They are densely clustered in leaf axils
Fruits1: Nearly spherical with Smooth and hard apperance
Fruits3: Taste is sour, bitter and astringent, and is quite fibrous
Fruits4: Six vertical stripes or furrows are present on them

Description: Originally from persian region. Ficus carica is a beautiful small species of  flowering plant in the mulberry family, known as the common fig (or just the fig). It grows wild in dry and sunny areas, with deep and fresh soil, it also grows in rocky areas. Anjeer is widely grown for its edible fruit throughout its natural range Iran and also in the rest of the Mediterranean region and other areas of the world.
Leaves4: They are fragrant
Flowers3: Bloom inside the ensemble of fruits
Fruits1: Flowers and seed sare borne inside fruit
Fruits4: Rich in iron, potassium, calcium and fiber

Description: Apta commonly known as Bidi Leaf Tree, is a small crooked tree with drooping branches, growing up to 3-5 m tall. Flowering takes place in February to May. In Maharashtrian families it is customary to exchange leaves of the Aapta tree on the Hindu festive day of Dussehra. An act known as exchanging Gold, pointing to the special significance of the plant on that particular day. This is also why the tree is often referred to as Sonpatta.
Leaves2: Swollen at base and at tip
Leaves4: They are used for making bidis
Fruits2: Pods are13 to 25cm long and 1.8 to 2.5cm wide
Fruits3: Each pod contains around 12 to 20 seeds
Fruits4: Seeds are compressed, reddish brown or black
Location: Inside Kshitij garden, Lakeside road

Description: It is a large shrub or tree growing upto 10 to 20 metres.This is the most common Indian species of Bridelia(Bridelia is a plant genus of the family Phyllanthaceae), mostly found in dry deciduous to moist deciduous forests, riverbanks, and rocky places. Found throughout the country excluding Andaman and Nicobar Islands and in Bangladesh, Nepal, Sumatra, Thialand, China, Shri-Lanka.
Leaves2: Base is rounded and tip is pointed
Leaves4: Each leaf contain15 to 20 parallel lateral nerves

Description: Ashoka is one of the most legendary and sacred trees of India. It is a rain-forest tree, native of Asia and South America. Its original distribution was in the central areas of the Deccan Plateau, as well as the middle section of the Western Ghats of Indian subcontinent. It is prized for its beautiful foliage and fragrant flowers. As a wild tree, the ashoka is a vulnerable species. It is becoming rarer in its natural habitat.
Leaves1: Young leaves are soft, red and limp
Leaves2: Deep green in color when mature
Leaves4: Compound, alternate and paripinnate
Bark1: Bark on old stems is dark green

Fruits3: Each pod contains around 6 to 8 seeds

Description: This tree is very popular in India. Ashok is commonly seen as a lofty column, very graceful with its downward-sweeping branchlets and shining, green foliage. Grows upto 25 to 30 feet. It is native to India and Shri-Lanka.The leaves are used for ornamental decoration during festivals. commonly planted due to its effectiveness in alleviating noise pollution.The tree is a main attraction in gardens throughout India.

Description: This is a fast-growing, crooked, gnarly tree in the family Fabaceae. Can grow upto a height of 15 to 30m. This plant is native to southeast Asia, Indonesia, Papua New Guinia and Australia. Used for the cultivation of the lac insect in India.This plant is raised as an ornamental plant, as a shade tree and it is also raised on plantations for fuelwood throughout southeast Asia, Oceania and in Sudan.

Description: This is a large tropical tree in the leadwood tree family Combretaceae, that grows mainly in the tropical regions of Asia, Africa, and Australia, reaches upto a height of 35m. The tree has a distinctive shape, its horizontal branches growing in wide spreading circles at different levels on the trunk. As the tree gets older, its crown becomes more flattened to form a spreading, vase shape. It is highly ornamental tree, much planted in avenues and gardens grown for its deep shade.

Leaves4: Before falling turn pinkish-reddish or yellow-brown

Description: This is a medium-sized lovely tree found in tropical forests in South Asia, Southeast Asia and northern Australia. Ornamentally prized for its dense shade and during the months from March to July fills the night air with the delicious heady aroma of its tiny cream colored flowers. People love to collect them as they retain their odor for many days after they fall.The wood is a luxurious wood that is extremely hard, strong and tough.
Leaves3: 5 to14 cm long, and 2.5 to 6 cm wide

Fruits2: Yellow when unripe, bright red-orange when ripe

Description: The banana plant is the largest herbaceous flowering plant, belongs to the family Musaceae. One of the most-important fruit crops of the world. The banana is grown in the tropics, and, though it is most widely consumed in those regions, it is valued worldwide for its flavour, nutritional value, and availability throughout the year. The fruit is variable in size, color, and firmness, which may be green, yellow, red, purple, or brown when ripe.

Description: Banyan is a large tree, reaches upto height of 20 to 25m, with wide leafy crown and branches spreading up to 100m or more. It produces propagating roots which grow downwards as aerial root.The tree is considered sacred in India, and temples are often built beneath. Due to the large size of the tree's canopy it provides useful shade in hot climates. The giant banyans of India are the largest trees in the world by area of canopy coverage.

Description: Indian Mulberry is a tree in the coffee family Rubiaceae. An evergreen shrub or small tree growing to 5 to 10m tall,native to Southeast Asia and Australasia. The plant is extensively cultivated in India in order to make the morindone dye sold under the trade name 'Suranji'. The colouring matter is found principally in the root bark and is collected when the plants reach three to four years of age.

Description: Bel is a species of tree native to the Indian subcontinent and Southeast Asia. A small to medium-sized tree, with slender drooping branches and rather shabby crown. The skin of some forms of the fruit is so hard it must be cracked open with a hammer.

Description: Ber is a small to medium sized subtropical tree, reaches upto a height of 15m, popular for its small berry like fruit. Grows vigorously and has a rapidly developing taproot, a necessary adaptation to drought conditions. This tree may be erect or wide-spreading, with gracefully drooping thorny branches, zigzag branchlets, thornless or set with short, sharp straight or hooked spines.

Flowers4: Born in clusters along the leaf axils

Description: Bitti is a poisonous large tropical shrub/small tree, native throughout Mexico and in Central America, and cultivated widely as an ornamental tree. All parts of this plant are toxic to most vertebrates. Contains many toxins that produce gastric and cardiotoxic effects. e.g vomiting,abdominal pain, nausea, pain in mouth and lips etc. Draught resistant and planted as ornamental tree in gardens and parks

Description: Bhokar is a small to moderate sized flowering tree in the borage family, Boraginaceae, with a short bole and spreading crown. It is a tree of tropical and subtropical regions. It is found in a variety of forests ranging from the dry deciduous forests of Rajasthan to the moist deciduous forests of Western Ghats and tidal forests in Myanmar.The timber is used in construction. The sticky, slimy fruit pulp is used to make glue.

Description: Royal Palm is a truly aristocratic palm which makes a memorable impression wherever it is grown. This is a large palm which reaches a height of 20 to 30 metres. Native to Mexico, parts of Central America, Caribbean, and southern Florida. It has been planted throughout the tropics and subtropics as an ornamental tree, looks especially impressive when formally massed along avenues and boulevards.

Description: Chanda is a resinious tree found in northern Thailand, Sri Lanka and India. Grows upto a height of 10m. Known as Kenda or Kanda in Sri Lanka. Young parts are velvet hairy. Leaves are commonly used for flavoring in Sri Lanka.They are also used to wrap jaggery and other sweetments.Today the major use of chanda is for making wooden pencils and plywood Industry.

Description: Chikoo is a fairly slow-growing, upright and elegant long-lived tree. Native to southern Mexico and Central America. Grows up to 18m high in the open but reaching 30m when crowded in a forest. It is strong and wind-resistant. Wood is strong and durable, used to make beams and furniture. Gummy latex (chicle) tapped from trunk during rainy season used for making chewing gum and adhesives.

Description: This is a distinctive narrowly conical tree growing up to 60m tall in its native habit, but more commonly grown as a house-plant in pots.The trees have a slender, spire like crown. A 2017 study found that trees tend to have a uniform tilt dependent on the hemisphere of their location, leaning on average 8 degrees south in the northern hemisphere and the same angle north in the southern hemisphere.

Description: The Coconut Palm is a member of the palm family. It is the only species in the Genus Cocos, and is a large palm, growing upto 30m. The term coconut can refer to the whole coconut palm or the seed, or the fruit, which, botanically, is a drupe, not a nut. Coconuts are known for their versatility ranging from food to cosmetics. They form a regular part of the diets of many people in the tropics and subtropics.

Flowers2: Male, female flowers in the same inflorescence

Description: Queen sago is a medium sized suckering cycad, growing 3 to 5 metres tall, exceptionally to 10 metres. Only gymnosperm species found among native Sri Lankan flora. the plant is classified as 'Endangered' in the IUCN Red List of Threatened Species(2011). It is now thought that Cycas circinalis is endemic to India, where it occurs in the Western Ghats, in the states of Kerala, Karnataka, Tamilnadu and Maharashtra.

Description: Dhaman is a moderate-sized to large tree, attaining a height upto 10m. and a girth of 2m. or more, belongs to Tiliaceae (Phalsa family). Globally distributed in tropical Africa, India and Indochina. Flowering starts in month of April. Fruiting throughout the year. The astringent and refreshing Grewia drupes are particularly popular in summertime. Bark/fruit juice is applied externally to relieve itching and to heal wounds faster.

Description: Shevga is the most widely cultivated species of the genus Moringa, the only genus in the family Moringaceae. It is a fast-growing, drought-resistant tree, native to the southern foothills of the Himalayas in northwestern India, and widely cultivated in tropical and subtropical areas where its young seed pods and leaves are used as vegetables. This tree used to combat malnutrition, especially among infants and nursing mothers.

It has been widely cultivated in subtropical and tropical climates worldwide and is a popular garden and park plant, as well as being used in temples and cemeteries.

Description: Indian charcoal tree is a species of flowering tree in the hemp family, Cannabaceae. A fast-growing shade tree with soft foliage.  Wood  of this tree is relatively soft, and burns easily and quickly when dry. The wood is suitable for paper and pulp production, producing paper with good tensile strength and folding endurance. Has a high ecological impact with at least 14 species of butterfly using it as a larval food plant.

Description: The Indian Cork Tree is mainly grown in gardens for its ornamental value. Sole species in the genus Millingtonia, native to South Asia & South East Asia. More commonly, it is used for making souvenirs and gift items.

Description: Indian Elm is a large tree, gowing up to 18m tall, belongs to family Ulmaceae (Elm family). Native to India, Sri Lanka, Myanmar and Indo-China. Crushed leaves emit an unpleasant odour. Flowering takes place in months of January and February while fruiting occurs throughout April and May. Excellent source of fodder for livestock.The bark of Indian Elm is used in rheumatism. Seed and paste of stem bark is used in treating ringworm.
Leaves2: Ovate or elliptic ovate with entire margin
Leaves4: 6 to 9 pairs of lateral prominant nerves
Bark3: Peeling in corky scales on old trees
Flowers2: Borne in short racemes or fascicles

Description: Indian rock fig is a tree which is commonly mistaken for peepal (Ficus religiosa).The leaf tips of Ficus religiosa are tapering, acuminate and long as against the leaf tips of F. arnottiana which are pointed and acuminate but not long. Globally distributed in India and Sri Lanka. Grows upto a height of 10m and aerial roots are absent. Flowering and fruiting occurs from December to April.
Leaves4: 5 to 8 pairs of lateral nerves, entire margin
Fruits1: Flowers and seed sare borne inside fruit
Location: Inside nursery

Description: Indian rubber tree is a large tree in the banyan group of figs, native to east India, Nepal, Bhutan, Burma, China, Malaysia, and Indonesia. Growing upto 30 to 40m , With a stout trunk up to 2m in diameter. The trunk develops aerial and buttressing roots to anchor it in the soil and help support heavy branches. Grown around the world as an ornamental plant. Yields a milky white latex, formerely used to make rubber.
Leaves2: Size is largest on young plats(Upto 45cm)
Leaves3: Size is much smaller on old plants(Upto 10cm)
Leaves4: Acuminate at apex, rounded at base
Flowers2: Bloom inside the ensemble of fruits
Fruits1: Small, multiple fruit, two fruits per node
Fruits3: Glabrous, yellowish green with dark spots

Description: The jackfruit tree, belogs to family Moraceae is well suited to tropical lowlands, and its fruit is the largest tree-borne fruit. The seeds from ripe fruits are edible. The jackfruit tree is a widely cultivated and popular food item throughout the tropical regions of the world. It is the national fruit of Bangladesh and Sri Lanka and the state fruit of the Indian states of Kerala and Tamil Nadu. Kerala is the largest producer of jackfruit in the world.
Leaves2: Top dark green, underside pale green
Leaves4: Pinnately nerved, with 5-12 pairs of veins
Flowers3: Present in spikes enclosed by spathe-like bracts
Flowers4: Male and female spikes present on same tree

Description: Jamun is a tropical tree in the flowering plant family Myrtaceae. Native to the Indian Subcontinent, adjoining regions of Southeast Asia, China and Queensland. A slow growing species which can reach heights of up to 30 m and can live more than 100 years. Its dense foliage provides shade and is grown just for its ornamental value. Fruit is a rich source of vitamin A and vitamin C. It has been spread overseas from India by Indian emigrants.
Leaves1: Simple, glossy, dark green, yellow midrib
Leaves4: Have an aroma similar to turpentine
Bark1: Base of the tree, the bark is rough, dark grey

Description: Kadamb is native to South and Southeast Asia. It can reach up to 45 m in height. A large tree with a broad crown and straight cylindrical bole. It is quick growing, with broad spreading branches and grows rapidly in the first 6 to 8 years. The flowers are used in perfumes. The tree is grown as an ornamental plant and for timber and paper-making. In Hindu mythology, Kadamb was the favourite tree of Krishna.
Leaves3: Ovate, 10 to 25cm long, 6 to12 cm wide
Leaves4: Pinnate, prominant,10-14 pairs of lateral nerves

Description: The curry tree (Murraya koenigii) is a tropical to sub-tropical tree in the family Rutaceae (the rue family, which includes rue, citrus, and satinwood), which is native to India and Sri Lanka. Its leaves are used in many dishes in India, Sri Lanka, and neighbouring countries. Fresh seeds and stems can be used for propagation. Leaves are also used to cure diarrhoea, dysentry and checking vomitting. Bark-paste is antisceptic, applied to skin eruptions.
Leaves2: Ovate, shiny, thin, dark green leaflets
Leaves4: Leaflet is 2 to 4 cm  long, 1 to 2cm broad

Description: This large tropical tree, reaches upto heights of 35m , indigenous to the Amazon rainforest, is listed as a rare tree and flower in India. Cultivated in many other tropical areas throughout the world because of its beautiful, fragrant flowers and large, interesting fruits. Fruits are spherical with a woody shell and reach diameters of up to 25 cm, which give the species the common name 'Cannonball tree'. The fruits take up to 1 to 1.5 year to mature.
Leaves4: Leaves are shedded twice a year
Flowers2: Petals are red inside, yellow outside
Flowers4: Strongly scented, especially fragrant at night

Description: The Cashew is a flowering tree, native to northeastern Brazil, where it is called by its Portuguese name Caju (the fruit) or Cajueiro (the tree). It is a small evergreen tree growing to 10 to 14m tall, with a short, irregularly shaped trunk. The cashew apple is a light reddish to yellow fruit, whose pulp can be processed into a sweet, astringent fruit drink or distilled into liquor. The cashew nut, often simply called a cashew, is widely consumed.

Leaves3: Lamina is 6 to 15.5cm long,  3 to 8cm wide
Leaves4: 10 to 15 pairs of parallel lateral nerves

Description: Hairy fig is a small but well distributed species of tropical fig tree, belongs to family Moraceae(Mulberry family). It is a Shrub to medium sized tree, up to 10 m tall. It occurs in many parts of Asia and as far south east as Australia. Like a number of ficus, the leaves are sandpapery to touch. Flowering and fruiting occurs throughout the year.

Description: Orchid tree is a species of flowering plant in the family Fabaceae. It is native to South Asia and Southeast Asia. Orchid tree is staggeringly beautiful when in bloom. It is a small to medium-sized tree growing to 10 to 12 metres tall, and sheds its leaves in dry season. This is a very popular ornamental tree in subtropical and tropical climates, grown for its scented flower, also used as food item in South Asian cuisine.

Leaves3: They are similar to camel's foot
Leaves4: 10 to 20cm long and broad

Description: Kaner is a shrub or small tree in the dogbane family Apocynaceae, toxic in all its parts. It is the only species currently classified in the genus Nerium. A native of India and the Mediterranean, now widely grown in tropical and subtropical gardens, parks, avenues, and is popular for its hue and fragrance. It rises up to 2 to 6 meters, erect with its short branches. Blooms from April to October, usually May and June are months of heaviest bloom.

Description: Karanj belongs to pea family Fabaceae. Native in tropical and temperate Asia including parts of Indian subcontinent, China, Japan, Malaysia, Australia and Pacific islands. Grows to about 15 to 25m in height with a large canopy which spreads equally wide. Karanj is increasingly used for oil production due to its use in biodiesel. In India, karanj has been traditionally used by villagers on slopy uplands to bind the soil.

Kassod starts flowering and fruiting at the age of 2-3 years. Once established, it flowers precociously and abundantly throughout the year. It is often used as shade tree in cocoa, coffee and tea plantations.

Description: Katesawar grows to an average of 20 meters, with old trees up to 60 meters in wet tropical regions. Native to India, tropical southern Asia, northern Australia and tropical Africa The trunk and limb bear numerous conical spines particularly when young, but get eroded when older. The flowers are very attractive to local wildlife. Honey bees, and bumble bees also attracted to the flowers to collect pollen and nectar.

Description: Senegalia Catechu is a thorny tree which grows up to 15m in height, and found in Asia, China, India and the Indian Ocean area. Branches of the tree are quite often cut for goat fodder and are sometimes fed to cattle. The tree's seeds are a good source of protein.The tree is often planted for use as firewood and charcoal, and its wood is highly valued for furniture and tools.

Description: Wild Date Palm is the wild cousin of the better known Date Palm. It is a species of flowering plant in the palm family native to southern Pakistan, most of India, Sri Lanka, Nepal, Bhutan, Burma and Bangladesh. It ranges from 4 to 15 m in height and about 40 cm in diameter. The fruit from this palm species is used to make wine and jelly. It has gained popularity in recent times as an ornamental tree in urban landscapes.

Description: Lemon, is a small tree in the Rutaceae (citrus family) that originated in Asia (likely India and Pakistan) It grows up to 6 m (20 ft) tall, and has stout spines. It is now grown commercially worldwide in tropical, semi-tropical, and warm temperate countries, including the Mediterranean region, for the fruit, which is used fresh and in beverages and cooking, and is also used as a preservative due to its anti-oxidant properties.

Description: Mangifera indica, commonly known as mango, is a species of flowering plant in the family Anacardiaceae. It is native to the Indian subcontinent, where it is indigenous. Hundreds of cultivated varieties have been introduced to other warm regions of the world. It is a large fruit tree, capable of a growing to a height and crown width of about 30m and trunk circumference of more than 3.5m. Mango is the national fruit of India, Pakistan and Philippines.

Description: Neem  is a tree in the mahogany family Meliaceae. It is one of two species in the genus Azadirachta, and is native to the Indian subcontinent. It is the state tree of Andhra Pradesh. Neem is a fast growing tree that can reach a height of 15 to 20m, rarely to 35 to 40m. The fairly dense crown is roundish or oval and may reach the diameter of 15 to 20 m in old, free-standing specimens. Its fruits and seeds are the source of neem oil.
Leaves4: Apex acute, margin entire, lateral nerves many
Fruits3: Greenish yellow with sweet bitter pulp
Location: Beside NSS nursery, beside ED building(Westside)

Description: Eucalyptus is an aromatic tree in the Myrtle Family (Myrtaceae) which commonly attains a height of 45 to 60m and a diameter of 1 to 2m. It is one of the most widely cultivated trees native to Australia. Its rapid growth and adaptability to a range of conditions is responsible for its popularity. It is especially well-suited to countries with a Mediterranean-type climate, but also grows well in high altitudes in the tropics.
Leaves4: Prominant 4 to 8 pairs of  lateral nerves
Bark3: Exfoliates in long white or brown strips

Description: Palas is a tree species, native to tropical and sub-tropical parts of the Indian Subcontinent and Southeast Asia. A Medium-sized dry season-deciduous tree, growing to 15 m tall. It is a slow growing tree, young trees have a growth rate of a few feet per year. It is said that the tree is a form of Agni, God of Fire. In Telangana, flowers of this tree are specially used in the worship of Lord Shiva on occasion of Shivratri. Telugu, this tree is called Modugu chettu.In villages of many parts of India, for example in Maharashtra, this tree provides leaves that are used either with many pieced together to make a leaf-plate for serving a meal over

Description: Parijat also known as Coral jasmine is a large shrub or small tree with spreading branches, growing up to 10 metres tall.The plant is particularly valued for its flowers which are used in traditional medicine, as a dye and a source of an essential oil. The plant has very fragrant flowers and is widely cultivated as an ornamental in tropical and subtropical regions all over the world. It is often planted near Hindu temples in India and Sri Lanka, as well as in Malaysia and Indonesia.The tree is sometimes called the 'tree of sorrow', because the flowers lose their brightness during daytime; the scientific name arbor-tristis also means 'sad tree'.
Leaves3: 6 to 12 cm long and 2 to 6.5 cm broad
Leaves4: Can be eaten with ginger to cure diseases
Flowers2: With five to eight-lobed white corolla
Flowers4: Open during night ,fall in the morning

Description: Ficus religiosa is a large dry season deciduous or semi evergreen tree up to 30 metre tall and with a trunk diameter of up to 3 m. It is one of the longest living growing tree in the world. It is unrivalled for its antiquity and religious significance. No other tree is claimed to have such long life: one in Sri Lanka, said to have been planted in the year 288 B.C., still lives and flourishes. It flowers in February and fruits in May to June. New leaves appear in April in India.
Leaves4: Apex caudate-accuminate, 8-10 pairs of lateral nerves
Flowers3: Bloom inside the ensemble of fruits
Fruits4: Ripening to purple with red dots

Description: Cassia is a genus of flowering plants in the legume family, Fabaceae, and the subfamily Caesalpinioideae. Pink Cassia is an ornamental garden and roadside tree. It is a small tree, reaches upto a height of 10m. In May when the large, showy flowers and tender, green leaves appear, it presents a strikingly beautiful picture, enhanced by the varied tones of pink in each small cluster. It is native to dry zone of upper Burma, now introduced into India and Malayasia.The ground under the tree is covered with a beautiful carpet of pink towards the end of the flowering season.

Description: The pomegranate is a fruit-bearing deciduous shrub or small tree in the family Lythraceae that grows between 5 and 10 m tall. It bears fruit typically in season in the Northern Hemisphere from September to February, and in the Southern Hemisphere from March to May. Pomegranates have beautiful orange-red trumpet shaped flowers with ruffled petals. It is widely cultivated throughout the Middle East and Caucasus region, north and tropical Africa, South Asia, Central Asia, the drier parts of southeast Asia, and parts of the Mediterranean Basin.
Leaves3: Narrow oblong, entire, 3 to 7 cm long and 2 cm broad
Leaves4: 6 to 8 pairs of lateral nerves

Description: An evergreen tree is a species of flowering plant in the pea family, Fabaceae. It is commonly called as peacock flower or Barbados Pride, is a fast-growing upright shrub or small tree which typically grows 3 to (in shrub form) 6 m tall (in tree form). It is native to tropical America (probably the West Indies), but is now widely grown in tropical areas around the world for its long bloom of colorful flowers.This beautiful treelet, is also called Dwarf Poinciana due to the resemblence of its flowers and leaves to those of Gulmohar.
Leaves4: Contains 6 to 10 pairs of leaflets

Description: Pride of India is a fast-growing, medium-sized, deciduous, sub-canopy tree with an upright, round crown. The tree usually grows 15 metres tall or more, with some specimens up to 26 m. The bole is around 60cm in diameter.It is grown in South East Asia, India and the Philippines. It is also widely cultivated as an ornamental plant in tropical and subtropical areas. A postal stamp was issued by the Indian Postal Department to commemorate flower of this plant.

Description: An attractive, large, spreading deciduous tree with a low, dense, dome-shaped crown; usually growing up to 30 to 60m tall. It is usually recognised by its umbrella like canopy, feathery foliage and puffs of pink flowers. It has a short, usually crooked bole that can be up to 200cm in diameter. It has been widely introduced to South and Southeast Asia, as well as the Pacific Islands, including Hawaii.

Description: A deciduous tree with a spreading crown of light, feathery foliage usually found in tropical region. It can reach upto a height of 6 to 20 metres with a bole up to 45cm in diameter.It is often found in countries like Brazil, especially in Caatinga vegetation, and in Costa Rica, Honduras, Cuba, Jamaica, Puerto Rico, Trinidad, Tobago, Venezuela, and the United States, especially in southern Florida. It is often grown as a specimen, several medical purposes and as a street tree.

It is generally  found growing between altitudes of 0 metres to 1,500 metres in different areas of Central America. It is also found in many parts of the world, including Southeast Asia, Taiwan, India, Bangladesh, Pakistan, Australia, and Africa. It is worldwide known for its sweet juicy fruit Custard apple.

Description: Sand Paper Tree is a rigid and densely branched tree growing to 4 to10m in height. This medium sized tree native to dry regions in Cambodia, Thailand, India, Sri Lanka, Malaysia, and Vietnam. It has been important in papermaking in Thailand for seven hundred years. True to its name, the leaves of Sand Paper Tree are rough and are utilized for cleaning cooking utensils and as a substitute for sandpaper.

Description: Saptparni belongs to family Apocynaceae. This elegant tree is native to the Indian subcontinent, Indomalaya, Malesia, and Australasia. On the Western Ghats, tribal people are reluctant to sit or pass under this tree, for the fear of the devil. Local superstition about its devilish character mainly stems from the fact that its milky sap which is poisonous, and thus the tree is shunned by cattle. Its bark is used in traditional medicine to treat dysentery and fever.
Leaves1: Simple, occur in whorls of 3 to 10
Leaves4: Obvate to oblong with entire margin
Fruits4: Seed ends have tufts of long hairs

Description: Shisham is a medium to large deciduous tree with a light crown. This tree is state tree of Punjab. Grows up to a maximum height of 25m with 2 to 3m in diameter. This fast growing tree is native to the Indian Subcontinent and Southern Iran. Shisham is best known internationally as a premier timber species. After teak, it is the most important cultivated timber tree in India. It is planted on roadsides and as a shade tree for tree plantations.

Bark3: Exfoliates in large pale brown flakes
Fruits4: Seeds are kideny shaped, thin, and flat

Description: Shivan is a fast growing deciduous tree, occurring naturally throughout greater part of India. It also occurs naturally in Myanmar, Thailand, Laos, Cambodia, Vietnam, and in southern provinces of China. It can grow from 3 to 30 metres tall, sometimes even taller. It has a chlorophyll layer just under the outer bark. The straight, cylindrical bole is around 50 cm in diameter. his tree is commonly planted as a garden and an avenue tree.

Leaves4: 3 to 6 pairs of pinnate lateral nerves
Flowers1: Small, yellow with orange pink shade
Fruits3: Yellow when ripe and has fruity smell

Description: Annona squamosa is a small, well-branched tree or shrub from the family Annonaceae that bears edible fruits called sugar-apples or sweetsops.It reaches a height of 3 to 6 metres.It is native to the tropical Americas and widely grown for its fragrant, juicy, and flavorful fruit.Sugar-apple is grown in lowland tropical climates worldwide, including in southern Mexico, the Antilles, and Central and South America, tropical Africa, Australia, Indonesia, Polynesia, and, in the U.S., in Hawaii and Florida.
Leaves3: Rounded at the base and pointed at the tip
Leaves4: Pale green on both surfaces
Bark2: Inner bark light yellow and slightly bitter
Flowers1: In short lateral clusters of 2-4 about 2.5 centimetres long
Flowers4: Petioles 0.6-1.3 cm long, green, sparsely pubescent
Fruits2: 5 to 10 cm in diameter, 100 to 600 gms in weight
Fruits3: The pulp is white tinged yellow edible and sweetly aromatic

Location: Inside most of the mostels, inside NSS nursery

Description: Star Gooseberry is a small deciduous tree reaching about 2 to 9 m in height. It is found throughout Asia and also in the Caribbean region, Central and South America but its origin is uncertain.The tree is occasionally cultivated as a garden plant in tropical areas for its fruit and as an ornamental use. It bears flowers and fruit mostly in January to May. Its fruit is used to make juice, pickles etc.
Leaves1: Obliquely ovate, acute or somewhat acuminate
Leaves4: Pinnate, 20-40 cm long
Bark3: In India, it is used as a tanning agent
Flowers3: Occurs in short dense spike like clusters in 5 to 2.5 cm long panicles
Flowers4: Cushion-shaped cymules at the nodes of leafless branches
Fruits1: Pendulous, in small clusters from the branches
Fruits2: Round,oblate or slightly flattened at the poles
Location: Inside NSS nursery

Description: Subabul is a small, variably shrubby and highly branched to medium-sized, fast-growing mimosoid tree native to southern Mexico and northern Central America.During the 1970s and 1980s, it was called  as a 'miracle tree' for its multiple uses.It has also been described as a 'conflict tree' because it is used for forage production but spreads like a weed in some places. It can grow upto 20m tall in arid tropical climates and can become a pest species in such climates.
Leaves1: 6-9 pairs of pinnae, looks same as of tamarind
Leaves4: Acute at tip, rounded to obtuse at base
Bark2: Deep red inner bark on older branches

Location: Lakeside road, beside LHC(Eastside), near T point

Description: A palm tree which produces popular betel-nut or supari, which is an essential ingradient of paan. It is a medium-sized tree growing to 20 m tall, with solitary, slender and erect trunk 20-30 cm in diameter and a crown of 10-20 leaves. It grows in much of the tropical Pacific, Asia, and parts of east Africa. The palm is believed to have originated in the Philippines,but is widespread cultivatied in southern China, Taiwan, India, Bangladesh, the Maldives, Ceylon, Cambodia, Laos, Thailand, Vietnam, Malaysia and Indonesia.
Leaves1: The leaves are 1.5 to 2 m long
Leaves4: Broad leaflets, the tips being jagged
Fruits3: Hardened supari is 1 to 2 cm in diameter
Fruits4: Has fibrous husk, Contain single seed
Location: Inside H2, H4, beside Gulmohar cafetaria(Westside)

Description: An evergreen tree with long needle-like branches and cone-like fruits, native to South Pacific to India.The species name equisetifolia refers to the resemblence of the leaves to a horse’s tail. The soft singing of the air through its innumerable slender twigs is a pleasant sound, which lends it the common name Whistling Pine.It grows 7-35 m tall. It is also found in  Southern United States and West Africa.It can produce tremendous numbers of small, winged seeds, which are dispersed by wind and water.The wood of this tree is used for shingles, fencing, and is said to make excellent hot-burning firewood.
Leaves1: Made up of tiny scales, six to eight in whorls
Leaves4: 7 to 8 per nodes
Bark3: Furrowed and flaking into oblong pieces on older trees
Flowers3: Male flowers occur in terminal spikes
Flowers4: Female flowers are in small, axillary clusters
Fruits4: Made up of winged nutlets each containing one seed

Location: Inside H9, H2, behind Gulmohar cafetaria(Eastside)

Description: An evergreen single-stemmed tall tree which attains maximum height of about 30 metres. It is native to South and Southeast Asia but can be found in Bangladesh, Cambodia, India, Jawa, Laos, Malaya, Myanmar, Socotra, Sri Lanka, Sulawesi, Thailand, and Vietnam.Worldwide, it is known for its fruit and tall height. People usually use its fruit to make Taddy(a drink) which is useful to fulfil their thirst during the summer.
Leaves4: Their stacks are 1 to 1.2m long
Bark4: Charcoal made of the bark serves as a dentifrice
Flowers4: Dioecious with male and female flowers occur on seperate plants
Fruits2: Has a black husk, and is borne in clusters

Location: Present all over the institute, Especially from Campus hub to Main gate road

Description: Tamarind (Tamarindus indica) is a semi-evergreen tree with large alternately arranged and pinnately compound leaves. It is a long-lived, medium-growth tree.It may reach a height of 10 to 20 m. It prefers to grow in clay, loam, sandy, and acidic soil types, with a high resistance to drought. India is native country for this species, but it can be found in Colombia, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Mexico, Peru, Puerto Rico, Venezuela, Italy, Spain, and throughout the Lusosphere where it is known as 'tamarindo'.
Leaves1: The leaves are about 3-8 cm  long
Leaves4: Leaflets close at night
Flowers3: Have five unequal lobes and borne in small drooping clusters.
Flowers4: can be eaten and sour in taste
Fruits1: Pod like fruit which contain an edible pulp
Fruits3: Sour in taste, huge source of citric taste

Location: Near H6, Lakeside road

Description: It is a tall growing deciduous tree generally occurs in forests. It grows upto 40 m tall.  It is sometimes known as the 'Burmese teak'. It is native to south and southeast Asia, mainly India, Sri Lanka, Indonesia, Malaysia, Thailand, Myanmar and Bangladesh but nowdays, it is cultivated in many countries in Africa and the Caribbean too. Myanmar's teak forests account for nearly half of the world's naturally occurring teak.It is specially known for its finest quality wood Hence used to make different type of furnitures. From November to January, the tree is leafless.
Leaves3: They are held on robust petioles which are 2 to 4cm long.
Fruits1: Pale green at first, then brown at maturity

Location: Near H15, beside Convo hall(Eastside)

Description: An evergreen tree but can be found deciduous near dry areas.The tree is native to Australia, Malaysia, Indo-China and the Indian subcontinent. The tree is 20 m tall and has irregularly-shaped, with wide-spreading branches and without aerial roots from the branches. In India, the tree and its fruit are called as 'gular' .It serves as a food plant for the caterpillars which helps them to grow and eventually they turn into butterflies.
Leaves2: Elliptical having 8-10 lateral pairs of vein
Leaves4: Used in treatment of Diarrhea
Bark3: Its bark has healing power hence used to heal wounds.
Flowers3: Bloom inside the ensemble of fruits
Fruits4: Ripe fruit is heavier to digest

Location: Near H9, T point, lakeside road, N2 bay, near Main gate

Description: An evergreen tree which usually grows in tropical climate. It grows upto 20 meter, and is part of Fabaceae family. It has short trunk, up to 1m thick .While tree appears evergreen, the leaflets are deciduous and shed in succession. It is useful against the treatment of fever and constipation. It is also used in treatment against cold. Its oil meal, pods and leaves are useful livestock feeds
Leaves2: Each pinnate consist of a pair of leaflets
Leaves4: Deciduous which shed in succession
Flowers2: Flowers are borne in small spherical glomerules
Flowers4: They form short axilary panicles 5-30 cm in length
Fruits1: Flowers produces pods which turn pink once rippen
Fruits2: Pod opens to expose an edible pulp
Fruits4: Pulp contain black shiny circular seed

Description: Sterculia foetida is a large, straight, deciduous tree growing to 40 m in height and 3 m in girth, with the branches arranged in whorls and spreading horizontally. Each branch contain 7-8 leaves. As tree keeps on growing, old branches sheds and new branch appears on the top.Its fruit is red in colour after ripe and is nutricious to health.The fruit is ripe nealy in February-March.
Leaves4: Generally appear in March and April
Flowers3: Unisexual, with male and female flowers on separate trees
Flowers4: Occur in panicles and 10-15 cm long
